Beside my death the curses of the country,
Troubles of conscience, and a wretched end,
Bring thee unto a poor forgotten grave.
My being: for another tongue to tell it,
Cease, a mother! some good man that dares
Speak for his King and country: I am full
Of too much woman's pity: yet o heaven,
Since it concerns the safety of my sovereign
Let it not be a cruelty in me
Nor draw a mother's name in question,
Amongst unborn people, to give up that man:
To law and justice that unrighteously
Has sought his father's death: be dease, be dease sir,
Your son is the offender, now have you all,
Would I might never speak again.
My son? Heaven help me.
No more I thought it: and since
His life is grown so dangerous: let them that
Gave him, take him: he shall die,
And with him all my fears.
O use your mercy: you have a brave subject
To bestow it on, I'll forgive him sir: and for his
Wrong to me, I'll be before ye.
Dared his villainy extend to thee?
Nothing but heats of youth sir.
Upon my life he sought my bed.
I must confess he loved me:
Somewhat beyond a son, and still pursued it
With such a lust: I will not say ambition,
That clean forgetting all obedience,
And only following his first heat unto me,
He hotly fought your death, and me in marriage.
O villain!
But I forget all: and am half ashamed
To press a man so far.
Where is the Duke? for god's sake bring me to him.
Here I am; each corner of the dukedom
Sends new affrights forth: what wouldst thou speak?
I cannot sir, my fear ties up my tongue.
Why, what's the matter? Take thy courage
To thee; and boldly speak, where are the guard?
In the god's name, cut with it:
Treason, treason.
In whom?
Double the guard.
There is a fellow sir.
Leave shaking man.
'Tis not for fear, but wonder. Leon. Well.
There is a fellow sir, close ith' lobby:
You oath guard, look to the door there.
But let me know the business.
O that the hearts of men should be so hardened
Against so good a Duke, for god's sake sir,
Seek means to save yourself, this wretched slave
Has his sword in his hand, I know his heart:
O it hath almost killed me with the thought of it.

sp.speaker: Leon.

lg.l: Where is he?

sp.stage: Enter the guard, and bring him in.

lg.l: The lobby sir, close in a corner:
Look to yourselves, for heaven's sake,
Methinks he is here already.
Fellows of the guard be valiant.
Go sirs, and apprehend him; treason shall
Never dare me in mine own gates.

sp.speaker: Tim.

lg.l: 'Tis done.

sp.stage: There they bring the prince in.

lg.l: And thou shalt find it to thy best content.
Are these the comforts of my age?
They're happy that end their days contented
With a little, and live aloof from dangers, to a King
Every content doth a new; peril bring.
O let me live no longer, shame of nature,
Bastard to honour: traitor, murderer,
Devil in a humane shape, a way with him,
He shall not breathe his hot infection here.
Sir hear me.
Am I or he your Duke? away with 'im
To a close prison: your highness now shall know,
Such branches must be cropped before they grow,
Whatever fortune comes, I bid it welcome,
My innocence is my armour: gods preserve you.
Fare thee well. I shall never see so brave a gentleman:
Would I could weep out his offences.
Or I would weep out mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Leon.

lg.l: Come gentlemen, we'll determine presently
About his death: we cannot be too forward in our
Safety: I am very sick, lead me unto my bed.

sp.stage: Exeunt. Enter citizen and his boy.

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.p: Sirrah, go fetch my fox from the cutlers: there's money for the scouring: tell him, I stop a groat since the last great muster: he had in store pitch for the bruise. He took with the recoiling of his gun.

lg.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: And do you hear? when thou come, take down my buckler, and sweep the cobwebs off: and grind the pick out, and fetch a nail or two: and tack on bracers: your mistress made a potlid on't, I thank her at her maid's wedding, and burned off the handle.

lg.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Who's within here, ho neighbour, not stirring yet?

lg.l: O good morrow, god morrow: what
News, what news?
It holds, he dies this morning.
Then happy man be his fortune, I am resolved,
And so am I, and 40. more good fellows
That will not give their heads for the washing, I take it.

sp.speaker: 2. Citizen
sp.p: Sfoot man, who would not hang in such good company, and such a cause? A fire a wife and children, 'tis such a jest that men should look behind 'em to the world: and let their honours, their honour's neighbour slip.

lg.l: I'll give thee a pint of bastard and a roll for that bare word,
They say that we tailors, are things that
Say one another, and our geese hatch us: I'll make some of 'em feel they are geese ath' game then,
I'fack take down my bill, 'tis ten to one I use it, take a
Good heart man, all the low ward is ours, with a wet
Finger.
And lay my cut-fingered gauntlet ready for me,
That that I used to work in, when the gentl: were
Up against us, a beaten out of town, and almost out a
Debt to, for a plague on 'em, they never paid well since,
And take heed sirrah: your mistress hears not of this
Business, she's near her time: yet if she do,
I care not, she may long for rebellion,
For she has a devilish spirit,
Come, let's call up the new ironmonger, is as
Tough as steel, and has a fine wit in these resurrections:
Are you stirring neighbour?
O good morrow neighbours,
I'll come to you presently.
Go too, this is his mother's doing: she's a polecat.
As any is in the world.

sp.p: Then say I have hit it, and a vengeance on her, let her be what she will.
Amen say I, she has brought things to a fine pass with her wisdom, do you mark it?

One thing I am sure she has, the good old Duke she gives him pap again they say, and dandles him, and hangs a coral and bells about his neck, and makes him believe his teeth will come again; which if they did, and I he, I would worry her as never cur was worried: I would neighbour till my teeth met I know where, but that's counsel.
Good morrow neighbours: hear you the sad news?

lg.l: Yes, would we knew as well how to prevent it.

sp.p: I cannot tell, methinks 'twere no great matter, if men were men: but —

lg.l: You do not twit me with my calling neighbour?

sp.p: No surely: for I know your spirit to be tall, pray be not vexed.

Pray forward with your counsel:
I am what I am, and they that prove me, shall find me to their cost: do you mark me neighbour, to their cost I say.

lg.l: Nay look how soon you are angry.
They shall neighbours: yes, I say they shall.
I do believe they shall.
I know they shall.
Whether you do or no I care not twopence,
I am no beast, I know mine own strength neighbours;
God bless the King, your companies is fair.

sp.p: Nay neighbour now ye err, I must tell you so and ye were twenty neighbours,

lg.l: You had best go peach, do, peach.
Peach, I scorn the motion.

sp.p: Do, and see what follows: I'll spend an hundred pound, and be two I care not, but I'll undo thee.
Peach, o disgrace: peach in thy face, and do the worst thou canst: I am a true man, and a freeman peach!

lg.l: Nay look, you will spoil all.
Peach!

sp.p: Whilst you two brawl together, the prince will lose his life.
Come, give me your hand, I love you well, are you for the action.

lg.l: Yes: but peach provokes me, 'tis a cold fruit,
I feel it cold in my stomach still.
No more, I'll give you cake to digest it.

sp.p: Shut up my shop, and be ready at a call boys, and one of you run over my old tuck with a few ashes, 'tis grown odious with toasting cheese: and burn a little juniper in my murrain, the maid made it her chamber-pot, an hour hence I'll come again; and as you here from me, send me a clean shirt.

lg.l: The chandler by the wharf, and it be thy will.
Gossip good morrow.

sp.p: O good morrow gossip: good morrow all, I see we of one mind you cleave so close together: come 'tis time, I have prepared a hundred if they stand.

lg.l: 'Tis well done: shall we sever, and about it?

sp.p: First let's to the tavern, and a pint a piece will make us dragons.

lg.l: I will have no mercy, come what will of it.

sp.p: If my tuck hold I'll spit the guard like larks with sage between 'em.
I have a foolish bill to reckon with 'em, will make some of their hearts ache, and I'll lay it on: now shall I fight, 'twill do you good to see me.
Come I'll do something for the town to talk of when I am rotten: pray God there be enough to kill, that's all.

lg.l: How black the day begins!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Can you blame it, and look upon such a deed as shall be done this morning?

lg.l: Does the prince suffer today?
Within this hour they say.

sp.speaker: Agen.
sp.p: Well, they that are most wicked are most safe: 'twill be a strange justice and a lamentable, gods keep us from the too soon feeling of it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I care not if my throat were next: for to live still, and live here, were but to grow fat for the shambles.

sp.speaker: Nis.
sp.p: Yet we must do it, and thank 'em too, that our lives may be accepted.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Faith I'll go starve myself, or grow diseased to shame the hangman; for I am sure he shall be my herald, and quarter me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I a plague on him, he's too excellent at arms.

sp.speaker: Nisus.
sp.p: Will you go see this sad sight my lord Agenor?

lg.l: I'll make a mourner.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If I could do him any good I would go, the bare sight else will but afflict my spirit, my prayers shall be as near him as your eyes: as you find him settled, remember my love and service to his grace.

lg.l: We will weep for joy sir, farewell.
Farewell to all our happiness, a long farewell.
Thou angry power, whether of heaven or hell,
That layst this sharp correction on our kingdom
For our offences, infinite and mighty,
Oh hear me, and at length be pleased, be pleased
With pity to draw back thy vengeance,
Too heavy for our weakness; and accept,
(Since it is your discretion, heavenly wisdoms,
To have it so) this sacrifice for all,
That now is flying to your happiness,
Only for you most fit: let all our sins suffer in him.
Gods, what's the matter! I hope 'tis joy.
How now my lords?
I'll tell you with that little breath I have;
More joy than you dare think, the prince is safe from
Danger.
How!
'Tis true, and thus it was; his hour was come
To lose his life, he ready for the stroke,
Nobly, and full of saintlike patience,
Went with his guard: which when the people saw,
Compassion first went out, mingled with tears,
That bred desires, and whispers to each other,
To do some worthy kindness for the prince.
And ere they understood well how to do,
Fury stepped in, and taught them what to do,
Thrusting on every hand to rescue him,
As a white innocent: then flew the roar
Through all the streets, of save him, save him, save him;
And as they cried, they did for catching up
Such sudden weapons as their madness show them.
In short, they beat the guard, and took him from 'em,
And now march with him like a royal army.
Heaven, heaven I thank thee,
What a slave was I to have my hand so far from
This brave rescue, t'had been a thing to brag on
When I was old. Shall we run for a wager to the
Next temple and give thanks?

sp.speaker: Nis.

lg.l: As fast as wishes.

sp.stage: Enter Leucippus and Ismenus: the people within stops.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Good friends go home again, there's not a man shall go with me.

lg.l: Will you not take revenge? I le call them on.
All that love me depart:
I thank you, and will serve you for your loves:
But I will thank you more to suffer me
To govern 'em once: more, I do beg ye,
For my sake to your houses.
Gods preserve you.
And what house will you go too?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ismenus I will take the wariest courses that I can think of to defend myself, but not offend.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: You may kill your mother, and never offend your father an honest man.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Thou knowest I can scape now, that's all I look for: I'll leave.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p:
Tima. A pox take him, would I had him here, I would kill him at his own weapon single scythes we
have built enough on him: plague on't, I'm out of all patience: discharge such an army as this, that would have followed you without paying, o gods!

lg.l: To what end should keep 'em? I am free.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Yes, free o'th traitors, for you are proclaimed one.

lg.l: Should I therefore make my selse one?
This is one of your moral philosophy is it?
Heaven bless me from subtleties to undo myself with;
But I know if, reason herself were here,
She would not part with her own safety.
Well, pardon Ismenus, for I know
My courses are most just; nor will I stain 'em
With one bad action: for thyself, thou knowest,
That though I may command thee, I shall be
A ready servant to thee if thou needst: and so I'll
Take my leave.
Of whom?
Of thee.
Heart, you shall take no leave of me.
Shall I not?

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: No by the gods shall you not: nay if you have no more wit but to go absolutely alone, I'll be in a little.

lg.l: Nay prithee good Ismenus part with me.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: I wonot i'faith, never move it any more; for by this good light I wonot.

lg.l: This is an ill time to be thus unruly:
Ismenus you must leave me.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Yes if you can beat me away: else, the gods refuse me if I will leave you till I see more reason; you shan't undo yourself.

lg.l: But why wilt not leave me?

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p:
Why I'll tell you, because when you are gone, then — life, if I have not forgotten my reason — he'll take me: you put me out of patience so: o!
marry when you are gone, then will your mother: a pox confound her, she never comes in my head but she spoils my memory to: there are a hundred reasons.

lg.l: But show me one.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Show you, what a stir here is, why I will show you: do you think; well, well, I know what I know, I pray come, come. 'tis in vain: but I am sure. Devils take 'em, what do I meddle with 'em? You know yourself. Soul, I think I am: is there any man ith' world? as if you knew not this already better than I. Pish, pish, I le give no reason.

lg.l: But I will tell thee one why thou shouldst stay:
I have not one friend in the court but thou,
On whom I may be bold to trust to send me
Any intelligence: and if thou lovest me
Thou wilt do this, thou needst not fear to stay,
For there are new-come proclamations out;
Where all are pardoned but myself.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and in the same proclamation your fine sister Urania, whom you used so kindly, is proclaimed heir apparent to the crown.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: What though, thou mayst stay at home without danger.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Danger, hang danger, what tell you me of danger?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Why if thou wilt not do't, I think thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: I dare not: if you speak it in earnest, you are a boy.

lg.l: Well fir, if you dare, let me see you do't.
Why so you shall, I will stay.
Why God a mercy.
You know I love you but too well.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Now take these few directions: farewell, send to me by the wariest ways thou canst: I have a soul tells me we shall meet often. The gods protect thee.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Pox o'me self for an ass, I me crying now, God be with you, if I never see you again: why then pray get you gone, for grief and anger wonot let me know what I say. I'll to the court as fast as I can, and see the new heir apparent.

lg.l: What hast thou sound him?
Madam he is coming in.
Gods bless my brother wheresoe'er he is:
And I be you keep me from the bed
Of any naughty tyrant whom my mother
Would ha' me have to wrong him.
What would her new grace have with me?
Leave us a while. My lord Ismenus,
I pray for the love of heaven and god,
That you would tell me one thing, which I know
You can do we'll.
Where's her fain grace?
You know me we'll enough, but that you mock,
I am she my sen.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: God bless him that shall be thy husband, if thou wearest breeches thus soon, thou'lt be as impudent as thy mother.

lg.l: But will you tell me this one thing?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: What is't? if it be no great matter whether I do or no, perhaps I will.

lg.l: Yes faith 'tis matter.
And what is't?
I pray you let we know where the prince my brother is.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: i'faith you shan be hanged first, is your mother so foolish to think your good grace can sift it out of me?

sp.speaker: Vrania.
sp.p: If you have any mercy left i'you to a poor wench tell me.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Why wouldst not thou have thy brains beat out for this, to follow thy mother's steps so young?

lg.l: But believe me, she knows none of this.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Believe you? why do you think I never had wits? or that I am run out of them? how should it belong to you to know, if I could tell?

lg.l: Why I will tell you: and if I speak false
Let the devil ha me, yonder's a bad man,
Come from a tyrant to my mother, and what name
They ha' for him, good faith I cannot tell.
An ambassador.
That's it: but he would carry me away,
And have me marry his master; and I'll day
Ere I will ha' him.
But what's this to knowing where the prince is?
Yes, for you know all my mother does:
Again the prince is but to ma me great.
Pray, I know that too well, what ten?
Why I would go to the good marquess my
Brother, and put myself into his hands, that so
He may preserve himself.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: O that thou hadst no seed of thy mother in thee, and couldst mean this now.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Why faith I do, would I might ne'er stir more if I do not.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I shall prove a ridiculous fool, I'll be damned else: hang me if I do not half believe thee.

lg.l: By my troth you may.
By my troth I do: I know I'm an ass fort,
But I cannot help it.
And won you tell me then?
Yes faith will I, or any thing else ith' world, for
I think thou art as good a creature as ever was born.
But ail go i'this ladst reparel:
But you must help me to silver.

sp.speaker: Ismenus.
sp.p: Help thee: why the pox take him that will not help thee to any thing ith' world; I'll help thee to money, and I'll do't presently to, and yet soul, if you should play the scurvy harlotry little pocky baggage now and cozen me, what then?

lg.l: Why, an I do, would I might ne'er see day again.
Nay by this light I do not think thou wilt:
I'll presently provide thee money and a letter.

sp.speaker: Ura.

lg.l: I but I'll ne'er deliver it.
When I have found my brother, I will beg
To serve him; but he shall never know who I am;
For he must hate me then for my bad mother:
I'll say I am a country lad that want a service,
And have strayed on him by chance, lest he discover me;
I know I must not live long, but that taime
I ha' to spend, shall be in serving him.
And though my mother seek to take his life away,
In ai day my brother shall be taught that I was
Ever good, though she were naught.

sp.stage: Enter Bacha and Timantus: Bacha reading a letter.

lg.l: Run away, the devil be her guide.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faith she's gone: there's a letter I found it in her pocket, would I were with her, she's a handsome lady, a plague upon my bashfulness, I had bobbed her long 'mass else.

lg.l: What a base whore is this, that after all
My ways for her advancement, should so poorly make virtue her undoer, and choose this time,
The King being deadly sick: and I intending
A present marriage with some foreign prince,
To strengthen and secure myself. She writes here
Like a wise gentle woman; she will not stay:
And the example of her dear brother, makes her
Fear herself, to whom she means to fly.
Why, who can help it?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now poverty and lechery which is thy end, rot thee, where ere to goest with all thy goodness.

sp.speaker: Timan.
sp.p: By’r lady they'll bruise her: and she wear a brass. I am sure they'll break stone walls: I have had experience of them both, and they have made me desperate: but there's a messenger madam come from the prince with a letter to Ismenus, who by him returns an answer.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: This comes as pat as wishes: thou shalt presently away Timantus.

lg.l: Whither madam?
To the prince, and take the messenger for guide.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What shall I do there? I have done too much mischief to be believed again, or indeed, to scape with my head on my back if I be once known.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Thou art a weak shallow fool: get thee a disguise, and withal, when thou com'st before him, have a letter feigned to deliver him; and then, as thou hast ever hope of goodness by me, or after me, strike one home stroke that shall not need another: dar'st thou speak, dar'st thou? if thou fall'st off, go be a rogue a again, and lie and pander to procure thy meat: dar'st thou speak to me.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sure I shall never walk when I am dead. I have no spirit madam, I'll be drunk but I'll do it, that's all my refuge.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Away, no more, then I'll raise an army whilst the King yet lives, if all the means and power I have can do it I cannot tell.

lg.l: Are you inventing still? we'll ease your studies.
Why how now saucy lords?
Nay I'll shake ye, yes devil, I will shake ye.
Do not you know me lords?
Yes deadly sin we know ye, would we did not.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Do you hear whore, a plague a god upon thee, the Duke is dead.

lg.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Ay, wildfire and brimstone take thee: good man he is dead, and passed those miseries which thou, salt infection-like, like a disease, flungst upon his head. Doffed thou hear, and 'twere not more respect in womanhood in general than thee, because I had a mother, who I will not say she was good, she lived so near thy time, I would have thee in vengeance of this man, whose peace is made in heaven by this time, tied to a post, and dried ith' sun, and after carried about and shone at fairs for money, with a long story of the devil thy father that taught thee to be whorish, envious, bloody.

lg.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: You fleering harlot, I'll have a horse to leap thee, and thy base issue shall carry sumpters. Come lords, bring her along, we'll to the prince all, where her hell-hood shall wait his censure; and if he spare thee she goat, may he lie with thee again; and beside, mayst thou upon him some nasty soul disease that hate still follows, and his end, a dry ditch. Lead you corrupted whore, or I'll draw good shall make you skip: away to the prince.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I hope yet I shall come too late to find him.
sp.stage: Enter loucippus, Iurana,: Leu, with abloudy handkercher.

lg.l: Alas poor boy, why dost thou follow me?
What canst thou hope for? I am poor as thou art.
In good faith I shall be we'll and rich enough
If you will love me, and not put me from you.
Why dost thou choose out me boy to undo thee?
Alas, for pity take another master,
That may be able to deserve thy love
In breeding thee hereafter: me thou knowest not
More than my misery: and therefore canst not
Look for rewards at my hands: would I were able,
My pretty knave, to do thee any kindness: truly
Good boy, I would upon my faith thy harmeless
Innocence moves me at heart, wilt thou go
Save thyself, why dost thou weep? Alas I do not chide thee.

sp.speaker: Urania.
sp.p: I cannot tell if I go from you, sir I shall ne'er dawn day more: pray if you can I will be true to you: let me wait on you: if I were a man, I would fight for you: sure you have some ill-willers, I would slay 'em.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Such harmless souls are ever prophets, well I take thy wish, thou shalt be with me still: but prithee eat, than my good boy: thou wilt die my child if thou fasts one day more. This four days thou hast tasted nothing: go into the cave and eat: thou shalt find something for thee, to bring thy blood again, and thy fair colour.

lg.l: I can not eat God thank you,
But I'll eat tomorrow.
Though't be dead by that time.
I should be well then, for you will not love me.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Indeed I will. This is the prettiest passion that ere I felt yet: why dost you look so earnestly upon me?

lg.l: You have fair eyes master.
Sure the boy dotes: why dost thou sigh my child?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: To think that such a fine man should live, and no gay lady love him.

lg.l: Thou wilt love me?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Yes sure till I die, and when I am in heaven I'll e'en wish for you.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: And I'll come to thee boy. This is a love I never yet heard tell of: come, thou art sleepy child, go in; and I'll sit with thee: heaven what portends this?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: You are sad, but I am not sleepy, would I could do ought to make you merry: shall I sing?

lg.l: If thou wilt good boy.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Alas my boy, that thou shouldst comfort me, and art far worse than I:
sp.stage: Enter Timantus with a letter disguised.

lg.l: Law master, there's one, look to your sen.
What art thou, that in this dismal place,
Which nothing could find out but misery,
Thus boldly stepped? Comfort was never here,
Here is nor food, nor beds, nor any house
Built by a better architect than beasts;
And ere you get dwelling from one of them,
You must fight for it: if you conquer him,
He is your meat; if not, you must be his.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I come to you (For if I not mistake, you are the prince) from that most noble lord Ismenus with a letter.

lg.l: Alas, I fear I shall be discovered now.

sp.speaker: Leu.

lg.l: Now I feel myself the poorest of all mortal things.
Where is he that receives such courtesies,
But he has means to show his gratefulness
Some way or other? I have none at all:
I know not how to speak so much as well
Of thee but to these trees.

sp.stage: Leucippus opening the letter, the whilst Timantus runs at him, and Urania's steps before.

lg.l: His letters speak him sir —

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Gods keep me but fro knowing him till I die: ay me, sure I cannot live a day, o thou foul traitor: how do you master?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: How dost thou my child? alas, look on his, it may make thee repentant, to behold those innocent drops that thou hast drawn from thence.

lg.l: 'Tis nothing sir and you be well.
O pardon me, know you me now sir?
How couldst thou find me out?

sp.speaker: Tima.
sp.p:
We intercepted a letter from Ismenus, and
the bearer directed me.

lg.l: Stand up Timantus boldly,
The world conceives that thou art guilty
Of divers treasons to the state and me:
But o far be it from the innocence
Of a just man to give a traitor death
Without a trial: here thy country is not
To purge thee or condemn thee; therefore
A nobler trial than thou dost deserve,
Rather than none at all, here I accuse thee
Before the face of heaven, to be a traitor
Both to the Duke my father and to me, and the
Whole land: speak, is it so or no?
'Tis true sir, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Take heed Timantus how thou dost cast away thyself, I must proceed to execution hastily if thou confess it: speak once again, is't so or no?

sp.speaker: Tim.

lg.l: I am not guilty sir.

sp.stage: Fight here: the prince gets his sword and gives it him.

lg.l: Gods and thy sword acquit thee, here it is.
I will not use any violence against your highness.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: At thy peril then, for this must be thy trial: and from hence forth look to thyself.
sp.stage: Timantus draws his sword, and runs at him when he turns aside.

lg.l: I do beseech you sir let me not fight.
Up, up again Timantus,
There is no way but this believe me.
Now if — fie, fie Timantus, is there no
Usage can recover thee from baseness? wert thou
Longer to converse with men, I would have chid
Thee for this: be all thy faults for given.
O spare me sir, I am not fit for death.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p:
I think thou art not; yet trust me, fitter than
for life: yet tell me ere my breath be gone, knowest of any other plots against me?

lg.l: Of none.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What course wouldst thou have taken when thou hadst killed me?

lg.l: I would have ta'en your page, and married her.
What page?
Your boy there. — dies.
Is he fallen mad in death, what does he mean?
Some good God help me at the worst: how dost thou?
Let not thy misery vex me, thou shalt have
What thy poor heart can wish: I am a prince.
And I will keep thee in the gayest clothes,
And the finest things, that ever pretty boy had given him.
I know you well enough,
Faith I am dying, and now you know all too.
But stir up thyself; look what a jewel here is,
See how it glisters: what a pretty show
Will this make in thy little ear? ha, speak,
Eat but a bit, and take it.
Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I prithee mind thy health: why that's well said my good boy, smile still.

lg.l: I shall smile till death an I see you.
I am Urania your sister-in-law.
How!
I am Urania.
Dullness did cease me, now I know thee well;
Alas why camest thou hither?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Faith for love, I would not let you know till I was dying; for you could not love me, my mother was so naught.

lg.l: I will love thee, or any thing: what? wilt
Thou leave me as soon as I know thee?
Speak one word to me: alas she's passed it,
She will ne'er speak more.
What noise is that? it is no matter who
Comes on me now. What worse than mad are you
That seek out sorrows? if you love delights
Be gone from hence.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Sir, for you we come, as soldiers to revenge the wrongs you have suffered under this naughty creature: what shall be done with her? say, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Leave her to heaven brave cousin, they shall tell her how she has sinned against 'em, my hand shall never be stained with such base blood: live wicked mother, that reverent title be your pardon, for I will use no extremity against you, but leave you to heaven.

lg.l: Hell take you all, if there be a place
Of torment that exceeds that, get you thither:
And till the devils have you, may your lives
Be one continued plague, and such a one,
That knows no friends nor ending.
May all ages that shall succeed curse you as I do:
And if it be possible, I ask it heaven,
That your base issues may be ever monsters,
That must for shame of nature and succession,
Be drowned like dogs
Would I had breath to please you.
Would you had love within you, and such
Grief as might become a mother: look you there,
Know you that face, that was Urania:
These are the fruits of those unhappy mothers,
That labour with such horrid births as you do:
If you can weep, there's cause; poor innocent,
Your wickedness has killed her: I'll weep for you.
Monstrous woman,
Mars would weep at this, and yet she cannot.
Here lies your minion too, slain by my hand,
I will not say you are the cause: yet certain,
I know you were too blame, the gods forgive you.
See, she stands as if she were inventing
Some new destruction for the world.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ismenus, thou art welcome yet to my sad company.

lg.l: I come to make you somewhat sadder sir.
You cannot, I am at the height already.
Your father's dead.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I thought so, heaven be with him: o woman, woman, weep now or never, thou hast made more sorrows than we have eyes to utter.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now let heaven fall, I am at the worst of evils, a thing so miserable wretched, that every thing, the last of humane comforts hath left me: I will not be so base and cold, to live and wait the mercies of these men I hate: no, 'tis just I die, since fortune hath left me my step descent attends me: hand, strike thou home, I have soul enough to guide; and let all know, as I stood a Queen, the same I'll fall, and one with me.
sp.stage: She stabs the prince with a knife.

lg.l: Ho.
How do you sir?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Nearer my health, than I think any here, my tongue begins to falter: what is man? or who would be one, when he sees a poor weak woman can in an instant make him none.

lg.l: She is dead already.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Let her be damned already as she is: post all for surgeons.

lg.l: Let not a man stir, for I am but dead:
I have some few words which I would have you heart,
And am afraid I shall want breath to speak 'em:
First to you my lords, you know Ismenus is
Undoubtedly heir of Licia, I do beseech you all,
When I am dead to show your duties to him.
We vow to do't.
I thank you.
Next to you cousin Ismenus, that shall be the Duke,
I pray you let the broken image of Cupid
Be re-edified, I know all this is done by him.
It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Last, I beseech you that my mother-in-law may have a burial according to — dies.

lg.l: To what sir?
There is a full point.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I will interpret for him; she shall have burial according to her own deserts, with dogs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I would your majesty would haste for settling of the people.

lg.l: I am ready.
Agenor, go and let the trumpets sound
Some mournful thing, whilst we convey the body
Of this unhappy prince unto the court,
And of that virtuous virgin to a grave:
But drag her to a ditch, where let her lie
Accursed, whilst one man has a memory.

lg.head: Cupid's speech.
lg.l: The time now of my revenge draws near;
Nor shall it lessen, as I am a god,
With all the cries and prayers that have been;
And those that be to come, though they be infinite,
In need and number.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
